values.description:
Switched from basic auth to auth0 authentication. To minimize effect on other repos that currently use cloudsim-auth, the server will only do user management for now and will still keep using csgrant tokens.

The new workflow should now be:

1. client authenticates through auth0 server, e.g. using `Auth0Lock`

1. once authenticated, client should request a csgrant token by doing a `GET` on `/token` and pass the auth0 token in the header (see index.js for example)


Other changes:

- remove our own user db stuff now that auth0 will handle user management

- updated landing page to use auth0

These env variables must be set, see internal wiki for info:

~~~
AUTH0_DOMAIN
AUTH0_CLIENT_ID
AUTH0_CLIENT_SECRET
~~~

[codeship](https://codeship.com/projects/156010/builds/17847332) - green

The new workflow should now be:

  1. client authenticates through auth0 server, e.g. using Auth0Lock

  2. once authenticated, client should request a csgrant token by doing a GET on /token and pass the auth0 token in the header (see index.js for example)

* Moved `supertest` to `devDependencies`

values.description:
The front end for our back-end-only servers is kind of empty. Why not use them for documentation? :bulb:

This is an experiment using https://swagger.io:

![swagger.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/Rknzjp/images/2192676655-swagger.png)

For completeness, I'll document how I generated this:

1. Install `swagger-ui` anywhere, no need to do it globally or to save it

        npm install swagger-ui

1. Copy the `swagger-ui/dist` folder to `cloudsim-auth/public`

1. This overrode the previous `public/index.html`, so now we're serving the example UI

1. Styled things a bit so they look more cloudsim-y

1. Constructed the [spec](#!/osrf/cloudsim-auth/pull-requests/new?source=swagger&t=1#Lpublic/index.htmlT47) object directly in the html file, we can find a more elegant solution later
values.title: Swagger REST API documentation

summary.raw:
The front end for our back-end-only servers is kind of empty. Why not use them for documentation? :bulb:

This is an experiment using https://swagger.io:

![swagger.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/Rknzjp/images/2192676655-swagger.png)

For completeness, I'll document how I generated this:

1. Install `swagger-ui` anywhere, no need to do it globally or to save it

        npm install swagger-ui

1. Copy the `swagger-ui/dist` folder to `cloudsim-auth/public`

1. This overrode the previous `public/index.html`, so now we're serving the example UI

1. Styled things a bit so they look more cloudsim-y

1. Constructed the [spec](#!/osrf/cloudsim-auth/pull-requests/new?source=swagger&t=1#Lpublic/index.htmlT47) object directly in the html file, we can find a more elegant solution later
summary.html:
The front end for our back-end-only servers is kind of empty. Why not use them for documentation?

This is an experiment using https://swagger.io:

For completeness, I'll document how I generated this:

  1. Install swagger-ui anywhere, no need to do it globally or to save it

    npm install swagger-ui

  2. Copy the swagger-ui/dist folder to cloudsim-auth/public

  3. This overrode the previous public/index.html, so now we're serving the example UI

  4. Styled things a bit so they look more cloudsim-y

  5. Constructed the spec object directly in the html file, we can find a more elegant solution later

values.title: Obtain username from Token

summary.html:
In this PR I address part of CLOUD-183 (the second PR in gz-token is here).

The username is no longer passed as a query, instead, it is inside the Auth0 Token.

Before, a GET request to /token would respond with null identities, as none was passed as a query. To pass any identity, it had to be included as /token?username=user. (Examples using a local Cloudsim Auth server)

curl -X GET -H 'authorization: Bearer auth0_token' http://localhost:4001/token

{
  "decoded": {
    "identities": [
      null
    ]
  },
  "success": true,
  "token": "{{cloudsim_token}}"
}

Now, as the username is included inside the Auth0 Token, the same command responds with:

{
  "decoded": {
    "identities": [
      "german@creativa77.com.ar",
      "teamGer"
    ]
  },
  "success": true,
  "token": "{{cloudsim_token}}"
}

This way we avoid passing the username in the query.

Notice that req.user contains the payload of the decoded token. It's email is in req.user.email.

Note: The obtained Auth0 Token can still be decoded and modified, but as long as the Client Secret remains secret, it's signature won't be correctly encoded, and an invalid signature error will be thrown upon decoding.

ptal @andres_fortier
